note.p: A letter from sir Wilfrid Bliss Spender (1876-1960) to his wife, Lady Lillian Spender, n√©e Dean, (1880-1968). In this letter, Spender expresses discontent that a few of his letters have been published in the press without his consent. He gives an account of his own situation, describing the surrounding countryside, the family who live in the chateau, and his strained relationship with a colleague. He describes a lacklustre 12 July, noting the exhaustion of the men. He asks Lillian to thank his mother for her donation to the Ulster Fund, congratulates Lillian herself on her continuing hard work, and hopes that that work might do something to bridge the class divide in Ulster.

Sir Wilfrid Spender (1876 - 1960) was a member of the British Army until 1913 when controversy surrounding his signature of the Ulster Solemn League and Covenant resulted in his resignation. Spender was called up for military service in 1914 and from 1915 served in the 36th (Ulster) Division. Throughout the war, Spender wrote a collection of letters to his wife Lady Lillian Spender. The letters date mainly from 1915 to 1918, when Sir Wilfrid was serving in France. The letters concern politics, the Irish question, personal life, and Wilfrid's experience of the Great War. Lady Lillian served in the Ulster Volunteer Nursing Corps during the war, and was an organiser of the Ulster Division Comforts Fund.

body.p:
I'm afraid letters are rather ragged just
now, but when one is on the move things
are always a little more difficult & I am
away from the ordinary post till tomorrow.

I thought you were at Sir Edwards
last week-end but find it is to be this one
so will chance sending a letter there.

I hope he is well & feeling well but
wish he could have seen his way to
have taken a more active part in
(or agin) the Government of the country.

I am getting a little restive at the
way my letters get into the papers! My
one to you was all right tho' only
intended for Mr G's private perusal, but I
wrote a personal one to Col Crawford &
an a letter of condolence ( with some
religious remarks) to Mr Davidson &
it never occurred to me that these
would be published. I suppose one ought not
to mind but it seems lacking in delicacy
& I should certainly have written very
differently had I known. I hope Craig
will not publish anything more — I have
sent him 2 letters — as one might get
into trouble & I hate to feel that I am
advertising the division.

Luckily in some ways Sir G also
published the General's letter & his orders.
He is rather livid about it. I also wrote
to Gen Powell & Sir G I do hope the
latter won't take mine to the Press! It is
private on the face of it.

I enclose a letter from Sir Ralph
Really it is nice of him to have written &
I appreciate it but I shall take him at
his word for the present & not answer

We are now in country like Norfolk
which is very much nicer than I
had expected but we move another 15
miles tomorrow when I expect the
country will be still flatter & more
full of dykes & perhaps less healthy

We expect to be left alone for some
weeks getting out drafts and training the men
-rather sad work in some ways as you
can understand especially as they will
not be our men.

The Lady of our chateau has 6
little daughters all stepping up 1 year
apart from 2 to 9. Rather like a p r
family tho' I don't quite fix yet
which is to be the p r of the bunch!!

The mother is teaching them music
and plays accompaniments to their scales
on the fiddle & simple exercises — vey
much like one's early school days.

P & I have got along much better lately
yesterday but I am afraid he overheard
yesterday a rather unguarded remark
I made to S which he probably resents
& will pay back.

Everyone here talks so well of the
division that one feels that one's
pride in belonging to it is not all
swank.

A sorry 12th July but our men
are wearing their lilies tho whether
bought or stolen or presented I don't
know. Most of them have had
long marches so I don't expect they
will do much drumming.

Saunderson aged 55(?) is to succeed
Farnham as ADC! He is said to have a
very rude manner & a bad temper but
this may pay with the G O C & Farnham
who has done splendid work has I
hope taught Harry his job.

I must write to Mater for her
most kind cheque some of which will
go to the Ulster Fund. Please tell her so
so that she may not feel bound to do
anything more for it. She really is a
wonder with her reduced income but
I don't think she ought or will be able
to continue these munificent presents.

My room is at the top of the Chateau
so nice & airy. I wish I could take
it or my hut with me

Please convey to Lady C how very
greatly I appreciate their kindness to you
& how much easier it makes things for
me to know that you have such kind
friends to look after you & to prevent
your work from becoming over burdensome.

Yes I am indeed glad you took up this
work & not the other now & I think you
are probably doing more for the future of
Ulster than either of us quite could of.
any neglect now would certainly spread &
make a gulf between the classes which the
UVF days have closed for a time.

Quite a good letter considering
which deserves a good mark but I see no
chance of getting i for a long time yet.
